Description: A scribal palette of grey slate: rectangular in shape, with two circular depressions for pigment. The palette is pierced by a hole at one end for hanging. Together with this object is a miniature spouted bowl of the same material, of correct size to stand in one of the depressions on the palette. Probably the two items did originally belong together, the vessel having been used to hold water for mixing the pigments.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Thebes (historic - Upper Egypt) (said to be from)
Curator's comments: Bibliography: A. Roveri and F. Tiradritte [eds.], 'Kemet: Alle Sorgenti del Tempo' (Ravenna, 1998), p.240 [210]; P. Pasini [ed.], 'Kemet: Guide all mostra' (Ravenna, 1998), p.17. See A. Scharff, ‘Die Altertümer der Vor – und Frühzeit Ägyptens’ (Berlin, 1929-31) II, no. 281 and pl.33; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Gizeh and Rifeh' (Warminster, 1977), pl.III (lower left); W. M. F. Petrie, 'Objects of daily use with over 1800 figures from University College, London' (London 1927), pl.LVI, 1-3. For the same form in ivory, see H. Bonnet, 'Ein frühgeschichtliches Gräberfeld bei Abusir' (Leipzeig, 1928), pl.31, 3.
Condition: Good condition, rim of the vessel repaired at one point and the spout slightly chipped.
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
